issues.description: Template repository's Farm.java does not define the class expected by the problem statement. The file declares a class named AnimalFarm and contains duplicated/nested package and class declarations (invalid Java) instead of a public class Farm with a List<Animal> attribute, constructor, getter/setter, and associated methods. This directly conflicts with the UML and textual description that require a Farm class and will prevent students from compiling or following the intended exercise (Main and the tests expect a class named Farm with the described members).
issues.suggested_fix: Replace the malformed template file with a proper Farm class declaration matching the problem UML: public class Farm { private List<Animal> animals; public Farm() { this.animals = new ArrayList<>(); } public List<Animal> getAnimals() { ... } public void setAnimals(...) { ... } public void addAnimal(Animal a) { ... } public void feedAllAnimals() { ... } private void singFarmSongVerse(Animal a) { ... } public void singFarmSong() { ... } }. Remove the duplicate/nested package/class declarations and ensure the file name Farm.java contains a class named Farm so students can compile and implement the described behavior (the solution repository shows a correct reference implementation you can mirror).

issues.description: The template's singFarmSongVerse method signature is inconsistent with the UML and the solution: the template has a commented-out Animal parameter and the method is implemented without accepting an Animal (the parameter is missing or commented). The UML and solution expect singFarmSongVerse(Animal animal): void and singFarmSong() should iterate over the farm's animals and call the verse method with each Animal. The current template signature and incomplete implementation will prevent students from properly implementing the verse printing logic and differs from the intended design.
issues.suggested_fix: Restore the method signature to accept an Animal parameter: private void singFarmSongVerse(Animal animal). Implement singFarmSong() to iterate over animals and call singFarmSongVerse(animal) for each. Inside singFarmSongVerse use animal.getClass().getSimpleName() and animal.messageOnFeed() as shown in the solution implementation to produce the correct verse output. This aligns the template with the UML and lets students implement/complete the method bodies as intended.

issues.description: The problem statement (UML and tasks) and the solution repository both define and refer to a class named 'Farm', but the template repository's Farm.java declares a public class named 'AnimalFarm'. This inconsistent class identifier (Farm vs AnimalFarm) breaks the one-to-one mapping students expect between the exercise description and the starter code, will cause compilation/name lookup errors (Main and tests refer to Farm), and forces students to resolve an unintended naming mismatch rather than focusing on the learning tasks.
issues.suggested_fix: Rename the public class in the template from 'AnimalFarm' to 'Farm' so the class name matches the problem statement and the solution. Ensure the file name remains Farm.java and update any internal references accordingly (e.g., method signatures and calls). This aligns starter code with the exercise description and the reference solution, removing an avoidable source of confusion.
